m5.desc: An alloy of superior strength and unknown origin.
m5.name: Xenosteel

m1.desc: An alloy of tin and copper.
m1.name: Bronze

r134.desc: a high pressure metamorphic rock containing talc and kyanite
r134.name: Whiteschist

r132.desc: a metamorphosed ultramafic rock with talc as an essential constituent; similar to a serpentinite
r132.name: Talc carbonate

r131.desc: a rock formed by partial melting during a meteorite impact
r131.name: Suevite

r130.desc: a low grade metamorphic rock formed from shale or silts
r130.name: Slate

r128.desc: a metamorphosed ultramafic rock dominated by serpentine minerals
r128.name: Serpentinite

r127.desc: a low to medium grade metamorphic rock
r127.name: Schist

r126.desc: a metamorphosed sandstone typically composed of >95% quartz
r126.name: Quartzite

r125.desc: a glass formed by melting within a fault via friction
r125.name: Pseudotachylite

r124.desc: a low grade metamorphic rock composed mostly of micaceous minerals
r124.name: Phyllite

r123.desc: a metamorphic rock with a protolith of quartz-rich (sandstone) sedimentary rock
r123.name: Metapsammite

r122.desc: a metamorphic rock with a protolith of clay-rich (siltstone) sedimentary rock
r122.name: Metapelite

r121.desc: a metamorphic rock formed by shearing
r121.name: Mylonite

r120.desc: a high grade metamorphic rock verging upon melting into a magma
r120.name: Migmatite

r117.desc: a metamorphic rock formed by heating by an igneous rock
r117.name: Hornfels

r116.desc: a mafic metamorphic rock dominated by green amphiboles
r116.name: Greenschist

r115.desc: a high grade metamorphic rock formed from basalt; also a facies of metamorphic rocks
r115.name: Granulite

r114.desc: a high grade coarse grained metamorphic rock with light and dark alternating bands
r114.name: Gneiss

r113.desc: an ultra-high grade metamorphosed basalt or gabbro; also a facies of metamorphic rocks
r113.name: Eclogite

r111.desc: a metamorphic rock composed of sodic amphiboles with a distinct blue color
r111.name: Blueschist

r110.desc: a metamorphic rock composed primarily of amphibole
r110.name: Amphibolite

r107.desc: particular sequence of sedimentary rocks which form within the deep ocean environment
r107.name: Turbidite

r106.desc: porous limestone formed by the precipitation of carbonate minerals from ambient temperature water bodies
r106.name: Tufa

r105.desc: sedimentary rock containing calcite and iron oxides
r105.name: Travertine

r103.desc: clastic sedimentary rock defined by 50% or greater silt-sized particles
r103.name: Siltstone

r102.desc: clastic, fissile sedimentary rock defined by clay-sized particles
r102.name: Shale

r101.desc: clastic sedimentary rock defined by its grain size (0.0625 mm to 2 mm)
r101.name: Sandstone

r100.desc: chemical sedimentary limestone formed from ooids, spherical grains composed of concentric layers
r100.name: Oolite

r99.desc: sedimentary rock composed dominantly of organic material
r99.name: Oil shale

r98.desc: clastic sedimentary rock that contains a mixture of silt- and clay-sized particles
r98.name: Mudstone

r97.desc: limestone with a considerable proportion of silicate material
r97.name: Marl

r95.desc: sedimentary rock composed of 60%- 70% organic material; otherwise known as brown coal
r95.name: Lignite

r94.desc: residual sedimentary rock formed from a parent rock under tropical conditions
r94.name: Laterite

r93.desc: an iron-rich chemical sedimentary rock similar to chert or banded iron formation
r93.name: Jaspillite

r92.desc: porous, yellow-orange sandstone which is flexible if cut into thin strips
r92.name: Itacolumite

r91.desc: essentially a coarse sandstone formed from small pebbles
r91.name: Gritstone

r90.desc: a type of sandstone with quartz, feldspar and rock fragments within a clay matrix
r90.name: Greywacke

r89.desc: opaline silica deposit formed around hot springs and geysers
r89.name: Geyserite

r87.desc: chemical sedimentary rock formed by accumulation of minerals after evaporation; varieties include rock salt (halitite) and rock gypsum
r87.name: Evaporite

r86.desc: a carbonate rock composed of the mineral dolomite +/- calcite
r86.name: Dolomite or dolostone

r85.desc: sedimentary rock formed from diatom fossils
r85.name: Diatomite

r84.desc: a lithified sedimentary deposit with a wide range of grain sizes
r84.name: Diamictite

r83.desc: a sedimentary carbonate rock formed by accumulation of abundant shell fossils and fragments
r83.name: Coquina

r82.desc: a sedimentary rock composed of large rounded fragments of other rocks
r82.name: Conglomerate

r81.desc: a sedimentary rock formed from organic matter
r81.name: Coal

r80.desc: a sedimentary rock formed from clay
r80.name: Claystone

r79.desc: a fine-grained chemical sedimentary rock composed of silica
r79.name: Chert

r78.desc: a sedimentary rock composed primarily of coccolith fossils
r78.name: Chalk

r77.desc: a sedimentary rock composed of > 50% detrital carbonate grains
r77.name: Calcarenite

r76.desc: a sedimentary or tectonic rock composed of fragments of other, broken rocks
r76.name: Breccia

r75.desc: a fine-grained chemical sedimentary rock composed of iron oxide minerals
r75.name: Banded iron formation

r73.desc: a sedimentary rock composed primarily of clay-sized particles
r73.name: Argillite

r72.desc: an ultramafic plutonic or cumulate rock, a type of peridotite, composed of olivine and clinopyroxene
r72.name: Wehrlite

r71.desc: a type of pyroxenite, composed of clinoproxene and orthopyroxene
r71.name: Websterite

r70.desc: a fine-grained volcanic rock formed from volcanic ash
r70.name: Tuff

r69.desc: a form of tonalite where plagioclase-group feldspar is oligoclase
r69.name: Trondhjemite

r68.desc: a plutonic ultramafic rock containing olivine, pyroxene and plagioclase
r68.name: Troctolite

r67.desc: a silica-undersaturated volcanic rock; essentially a feldspathoid-bearing rhyolite
r67.name: Trachyte

r60.desc: a plutonic rock dominated by orthoclase feldspar; a type of granitoid
r60.name: Syenite

r58.desc: an extremely vesicular mafic volcanic rock
r58.name: Scoria

r57.desc: an alkaline rhyolite-rhyodacite with amphibole phenocrysts
r57.name: Pantellerite

r54.desc: a felsic volcanic rock which is intermediate between a rhyolite and a dacite
r54.name: Rhyodacite

r53.desc: an intrusive rock composed mostly of quartz
r53.name: Quartzolite

r52.desc: an intermediate plutonic rock, essentially a monzonite with 5-10% modal quartz
r52.name: Quartz monzonite

r50.desc: a coarse grained plutonic rock composed of >90% pyroxene
r50.name: Pyroxenite

r49.desc: a fine grained, vesicular volcanic rock
r49.name: Pumice

r48.desc: a rock, usually granitic, with a porphyritic texture
r48.name: Porphyry

r46.desc: a silica-undersaturated volcanic rock; essentially similar to nepheline syenite
r46.name: Phonolite

r45.desc: a plutonic or cumulate ultramafic rock composed of olivine and pyroxene
r45.name: Peridotite

r44.desc: an igneous rock (or metamorphic) rock with crystals >1 inch, usually granitic
r44.name: Pegmatite

r41.desc: a silica-undersaturated plutonic rock with >90% nepheline
r41.name: Nephelinite

r40.desc: a silica-undersaturated plutonic rock of nepheline and alkali feldspar
r40.name: Nepheline syenite

r39.desc: a plutonic rock with <5% normative quartz
r39.name: Monzonite

r38.desc: a silica-undersaturated granite with <5% normative quartz
r38.name: Monzogranite

r37.desc: an ultramafic rock, essentially a peridotite
r37.name: Lherzolite

r35.desc: an ultramafic, ultrapotassic intrusive rock dominated by mafic phenocrysts in a feldspar groundmass
r35.name: Lamprophyre

r33.desc: an ultramafic volcanic rock with very high magnesium content
r33.name: Komatiite

r32.desc: a rare ultramafic, ultrapotassic volcanic rock and a source of diamonds
r32.name: Kimberlite

r31.desc: a very rare silica-undersaturated plutonic rock
r31.name: Ijolite

r28.desc: a volcanic rock composed primarily of glasses and glassy tuff
r28.name: Hyaloclastite

r27.desc: a mafic or ultramafic cumulate rock dominated by >90% hornblende
r27.name: Hornblendite

r26.desc: a variety of peridotite; an ultramafic cumulate rock
r26.name: Harzburgite

r25.desc: a subvolcanic intrusive rock of granitic composition
r25.name: Granophyre

r24.desc: a granitic plutonic rock with more plagioclase than orthoclase
r24.name: Granodiorite

r23.desc: a coarse-grained plutonic rock composed of orthoclase, plagioclase and quartz
r23.name: Granite

r22.desc: a coarse-grained plutonic rock composed of pyroxene and plagioclase basically equivalent to basalt
r22.name: Gabbro

r21.desc: a plutonic igneous rock composed of >90% feldspathoid minerals
r21.name: Foidolite

r20.desc: a silica-undersaturated mafic plutonic rock (essentially a feldspathoid-bearing gabbro)
r20.name: Essexite

r19.desc: a phaneritic ultramafic rock composed of more than 90% olivine
r19.name: Dunite

r18.desc: a variety of diorite which is characterized by orbicular structure. Also called corsite.
r18.name: Napoleonite

r17.desc: a coarse-grained intermediate plutonic rock composed of plagioclase, pyroxene and/or amphibole
r17.name: Diorite

r16.desc: an intrusive mafic rock forming dykes or sills
r16.name: Diabase

r15.desc: a felsic to intermediate volcanic rock containing hornblende and with more plagioclase than orthoclase
r15.name: Dacite

r13.desc: a type of granite containing orthopyroxene
r13.name: Charnockite

r12.desc: a rare igneous rock composed of >50% carbonate minerals
r12.name: Carbonatite

r11.desc: a magnesium-rich basalt dominated by pyroxene
r11.name: Boninite

r9.desc: a volcanic rock of mafic composition; essentially a silica-undersaturated basalt
r9.name: Basanite

r8.desc: a type of basalt, typically formed by ocean island (hot spot) volcanism
r8.name: Hawaiite

r7.desc: basaltic lava with a flowing, often ropy appearance
r7.name: Pahoehoe

r6.desc: a volcanic rock of mafic composition
r6.name: Basalt

r5.desc: a very fine-grained intrusive igneous rock composed of quartz and feldspar, similar composition to granite but with grains <1mm
r5.name: Aplite

r4.desc: a mafic intrusive igneous rock composed predominantly of plagioclase
r4.name: Anorthosite

r3.desc: a granitoid in which at least 90% of the total feldspar is in the form of alkali feldspar
r3.name: Alkali feldspar granite

r1.desc: a class of intermediate to felsic rocks containing low amounts of yttrium and ytterbium
r1.name: Adakite
